item.title: Celebrating Atlantic City’s Business Icons: A Street Dedication to Entrepreneurial Excellence
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue pays tribute to the couple who owned and operated multiple McDonald’s franchises in Atlantic City for four decades.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City community has been lovin’ longtime Atlantic City McDonald’s owners Rita and Anthony Mack for the last four decades, and they’ve been lovin’ the community right back. And now, the City of Atlantic City has honored these two community icons with a street dedication recognizing their nearly 40 years of business excellence, community impact, and entrepreneurial leadership in the city.

Arctic Avenue between Michigan and Arkansas Avenues has been named Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue, paying tribute to the couple who owned and operated multiple McDonald’s franchises in Atlantic City, with their first one purchased in June 1986 and final one sold in May 2024 as they embarked on a much-deserved retirement.

The Macks are the definition of successful entrepreneurship in Atlantic City. Long before casinos dominated the city’s economy, there was a generation of African American business leaders who built strong, community-based enterprises that anchored neighborhoods and provided opportunity. Today, as Atlantic City’s Economic Development division under the Department of Planning and Development works to revitalize that same spirit of local ownership and empowerment, the Macks stand as living proof that businesses –especially minority-owned ones - can not only survive but thrive in Atlantic City. Rita and Anthony Mack have been the blueprint for success, showing what’s possible through hard work, generosity, and a deep commitment to community.

“We really appreciate your many years of service, your selflessservice, and your dedication to the Great City of Atlantic City community," Mayor Small told the Macks during the Street Dedication Ceremony in theirhonor. It was during this ceremony that the couple also received a customstreet sign to take home, symbolizing the enduring legacy they have built.

Rita and Anthony Mack expressed deep gratitude for the recognition and for the community that supported them from the beginning.

“We are incredibly honored and humbled to receive this awesome recognition,” said Rita Mack. “The renaming of this city block to Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue is an undeniable dream for us. It’s the very block where we began our business journey in 1986, and we are thrilled beyond belief.”

Reflecting on their journey, Rita added:

“They say the most critical factors in choosing a franchise arelocation, location, location. I must say, we struck gold when we purchased ourArkansas Avenue site. But we were also blessed to find ourselves in asupportive and caring community. From the very beginning, this community hasembraced and supported us in so many ways.”

The Macks hope that others — especially young people and aspiringentrepreneurs — will be inspired each time they pass Rita and Anthony MackAvenue, a lasting reminder that dreams can be built right here in Atlantic City.

Their name now rightfully takes its place in the heart of Atlantic City in recognition of their extraordinary contributions.

item.title: Atlantic City Council Honored Officers Glen Robinson and Alex Torres for Exceptional Service
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Council honored Officers Glen Robinson and Alex Torres for their swift response and professionalism during an attempted vehicle theft incident. Their teamwork and vigilance led to the arrest of the suspect and reinforced the city’s commitment to public safety.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Council proudly recognized Officers Glen Robinson and Alex Torres for their outstanding professionalism and quick action during a recent incident that demonstrated exceptional teamwork and dedication to duty.

While on patrol, Officers Robinson and Torres responded swiftly to a report involving an attempted vehicle theft. Thanks to their quick and coordinated response, the officers were able to identify and arrest the suspect, who was later charged with theft and burglary.

Their decisive actions not only prevented a crime from being completed but also reinforced the department’s commitment to maintaining public safety and protecting the residents of Atlantic City.

During the Atlantic City Council meeting, Officer Glen Robinson was present to receive his Certificate of Commendation, while Officer Alex Torres, who was unable to attend, was also honored for his role in the successful apprehension.

Adding a personal note to the recognition, Council President Aaron “Sporty” Randolph—whose vehicle had been the target in the attempted theft—presented Officer Torres’ commendation on behalf of the department.

Council members commended both officers for their professionalism, vigilance, and effective teamwork, which served as a model of what community policing represents in Atlantic City.

The recognition highlighted the department’s emphasis on accountability, dedication, and excellence in service to the community.

By acknowledging officers who go above and beyond their call of duty, Atlantic City Council continues to strengthen the partnership between law enforcement and the public.

The event served as a reminder of the vital role that police officers play in ensuring the safety and well-being of all residents.

item.title: Deadline Approaching! Atlantic City Invites Small Businesses to Apply for Micro Grant Program—Up to $15,000 Available
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City is now accepting applications for its Small Business Micro Grant Program, offering up to $15,000 in funding to help local entrepreneurs recover and grow. Applications are open until October 31, 2025, and can be submitted online, by email, or in person through the Department of Planning & Development.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City is once again investing in its small business community through the Small Business Micro Grant Program, offering eligible for-profit businesses the chance to receive up to $15,000 in grant funding. Made possible through over $400,000 in federal funding from the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA), this initiative aims to help local businesses recover from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, retain jobs, and strengthen long-term growth.

The program supports both existing small businesses and startups operating within Atlantic City limits. Funds can be used for a range of operational costs—including payroll, rent, mortgage, utilities, equipment, inventory, and other pandemic-related expenses incurred between March 3, 2021, and October 1, 2023. Startups established in 2022 or later may also qualify.

“This program continues to fulfill Mayor Marty Small, Sr.’s vision of strengthening Atlantic City’s local economy by supporting small businesses,” said Bruce Weekes, Assistant Director of Economic Development. “We encourage all eligible businesses—especially those that have previously participated in city programs—to apply and take advantage of this funding opportunity.”

Who Can Apply:
To qualify, applicants must:
  • Be a for-profit business located in Atlantic City (or planning to locate there)
  • Employ 50 or fewer people
  • Be independently owned and operated
  • Be registered in New Jersey
  • Provide documentation showing financial hardship due to the pandemic

Startups must also submit a current business plan and a short narrative explaining how COVID-19 affected their operations.

How to Apply:
Applications are now open and will be accepted until October 31, 2025. Early submission is strongly encouraged, as applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis.

Applicants must submit a completed application packet in one of the following ways:

  1. By Email: Send your full application to bweekes@acnj.gov
  2. By Mail or In Person:
    Department of Planning & Development
    Attn: Bruce Weekes
    1301 Bacharach Blvd., Suite 506
    Atlantic City, NJ 08401

Application materials and full program guidelines, including a list of required documents for both existing businesses and startups, can be downloaded from www.acnj.gov or picked up in person at the address above.

For any questions or to confirm eligibility, applicants are encouraged to contact Bruce Weekes directly by email or by calling 609-347-5544. Those visiting in person are asked to reach out ahead of time to arrange pickup.

This program is part of the Small Administration’s ongoing commitment to supporting small businesses, increasing economic diversity, and helping entrepreneurs succeed in Atlantic City. It complements other free programs offered through the Economic Development Division, including the Small Business Academy, Credit Repair Program, Investment Cohort, and marketing workshops designed to help business owners grow with little-to-no budget.

With programs like these, Atlantic City continues to prove that it’s a place to live, work, and thrive—where small businesses can turn ideas into success stories and help drive the city’s bright economic future.

item.title: Atlantic City to Launch Food Truck Operations at Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City will launch its new food truck operations on November 1, 2025, at Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park, creating fresh opportunities for small businesses and offering residents and visitors more local dining options in two of the city’s most vibrant public spaces.
item.content:encoded:
Get ready to taste something new in Atlantic City! Starting November 1, 2025, the city will officially launch its food truck operations at two popular public destinations—Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park—bringing more dining variety, energy, and opportunity to the community.

Approved unanimously by City Council earlier this year, this initiative reflects Atlantic City’s growing commitment to supporting small businesses and enhancing its outdoor spaces. The Office of Economic Development and Department of Planning & Development have been working closely with Public Works and Licensing & Inspection to prepare each site with new signage, designated vendor spaces, and clear operating guidelines to ensure a smooth launch.

At O’Donnell Memorial Park, food trucks will be positioned along Captain John O’Donnell Parkway, offering easy access for residents and visitors exploring the area. Meanwhile, at Gardner’s Basin, trucks will operate along the roadway between the Seawall parking lot and the Atlantic City Aquarium, providing guests with convenient and delicious options by the water.

Each location will accommodate up to eight registered and approved food trucks, operating daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM. Interested vendors can now apply through the City of Atlantic City website at www.acnj.gov. Applications open on October 6, 2025, under the Licensing & Inspection section—simply select Food Truck under Business Licenses/Mercantile.

“This is another exciting step in showing that Atlantic City is open for business,” said Mayor Marty Small, Sr. “We’re creating opportunities for small businesses, generating tax revenue, and giving residents and visitors more affordable food options in two of our most visited public areas.”

Bruce Weekes, Assistant Director of Economic Development, added, “Residents have asked for this for years—and we listened. Our goal is for this program to serve as a stepping stone for food operators to establish themselves right here in Atlantic City, grow their brands, and eventually open permanent storefronts.”

All participating food trucks will be inspected and approved by the City of Atlantic City Health Department and the Atlantic City Fire Department before operation. Vendors will be responsible for maintaining cleanliness and following all city regulations. Please note that the sale of alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis is strictly prohibited.

With this new initiative, Atlantic City continues to prove that it’s not just a destination—it’s a community of opportunity, where entrepreneurs can thrive and residents can enjoy diverse, local experiences every day.

item.title: Atlantic City’s Winter Wonderland Parade Returns—Now Brighter Than Ever
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City’s Winter Wonderland Parade is returning on December 6 with a brand-new evening format—promising dazzling lights, glowing floats, and festive cheer for the whole community, followed by a post-parade celebration in O’Donnell Memorial Park.
item.content:encoded:
This holiday season, Atlantic City is adding even more sparkle to one of its most beloved traditions. The Winter Wonderland Parade is returning—this time with a magical evening format that will light up the city with glowing floats, twinkling displays, and the joyful sounds of the season.

Mark your calendars for Saturday, December 6, 2025, when the parade will begin at 4:30 PM at Rhode Island Avenue (staging at New Hampshire Avenue) and make its way down Atlantic Avenue to Albany Avenue. The new evening schedule promises to transform Atlantic City’s streets into a shimmering holiday spectacle for families, visitors, and neighbors alike.

Last year’s Winter Wonderland Parade featured nearly 100 participants, and this year’s event is expected to be even bigger, brighter, and more spectacular. The City of Atlantic City is inviting schools, community groups, local businesses, and performers to take part in this year’s parade and showcase their creativity in a festive display of community spirit. Participant registration is now open, with applications and submission instructions available at www.acnj.gov.

“This year’s Winter Wonderland Parade will be one of the biggest and brightest events in Atlantic City history,” said Mayor Marty Small, Sr. “The move to nighttime adds a whole new layer of holiday magic, and switching the route to Atlantic Avenue helps us get all our neighborhoods more involved. We can’t wait to bring our community together to celebrate the most wonderful time of the year once again.”

The celebration doesn’t end when the parade does. After the final float rolls by, families can continue the fun at a post-parade celebration in O’Donnell Memorial Park, featuring music, entertainment, and more seasonal cheer.

And that’s not all—Atlantic City’s fall festivities are getting a fresh new look this year too. Formerly known as the Harvest Festival, the newly named Harvest Town will take place on October 25, 2025, from 2:00 PM to 6:00 PM at Gardner’s Basin. The event will feature delicious food, games, rides, fall-themed activities, and candy giveaways for children (costumes encouraged).

Local nonprofits, community organizations, and small businesses are encouraged to join both events by setting up booths, sharing resources, and celebrating the season with Atlantic City families.

For questions or participation inquiries, contact the Mayor’s Office of Special Events at 609-347-5823.

Atlantic City continues to prove that it’s more than just a destination—it’s a community full of heart, creativity, and celebration, where families come together to live, work, and make lasting memories all year long.

Participants appreciated the careful planning and smooth coordination that ensured a stress-free day from departure to return. Every detail—from transportation to timing—was thoughtfully managed, allowing everyone to simply relax and enjoy.

The day’s success highlighted the importance of creating moments that celebrate both art and togetherness, reminding everyone that joy and discovery have no age limit.

The trip concluded with smiles, photos, and heartfelt gratitude from the attendees, who described it as a truly great day with great people.

item.title: City of Atlantic City Kicked Off Leaf Collection Season in Lower Chelsea
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City launched its annual Leaf Collection Season in Lower Chelsea, encouraging residents to rake or blow their leaves to the curb for collection by the Department of Public Works. Additional neighborhood dates will follow in the coming weeks.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City’s Department of Public Works officially kicked off the annual Leaf Collection Season last weekend, beginning in the Lower Chelsea neighborhood. The initiative aimed to help residents maintain clean surroundings as the fall season brought an abundance of leaves across the city.

Starting on Saturday, October 18th, from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM, city crews made their rounds to collect leaves that residents had placed along curbs and streets. This effort was part of a citywide schedule that ensured each neighborhood would receive dedicated collection days in the coming weeks.

Residents were encouraged to actively participate by blowing or raking their leaves to the curb or street on their designated dates. Once in place, the Department of Public Works took charge of collecting and properly disposing of them, helping to prevent clogged drains, improve neighborhood cleanliness, and support environmental upkeep.

The city emphasized the importance of cooperation during this seasonal program, reminding residents that properly placed leaves would make collection more efficient and help maintain the beauty of local communities.

The Public Works team also assured the public that additional neighborhood collection dates would be announced as soon as they became available, keeping everyone informed through official channels.

As the city transitioned deeper into the autumn season, the initiative served as a reminder of the City of Atlantic City’s commitment to maintaining clean, safe, and attractive neighborhoods.

The Leaf Collection Season demonstrated how community collaboration and proactive planning could make a visible difference in keeping Atlantic City beautiful.

The program also reinforced the city’s ongoing dedication to environmental care and the well-being of its residents, ensuring that seasonal changes were handled efficiently and responsibly.

This annual initiative continues to be a valued effort, fostering community pride and enhancing the city’s overall appearance during the fall months.

item.title: Atlantic City Residents Gained Life-Saving Knowledge at Flood Safety Workshop
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City held a Flood Safety Workshop that empowered residents with vital knowledge on flood preparedness and safety. The timely event, organized before a major flooding incident, provided participants with FREE Flooding Preparedness Kits and practical tips to protect their homes and families.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City successfully held a Flood Safety Workshop last week, providing residents with critical information and resources to stay safe during flooding events. The session, organized months in advance, proved to be incredibly timely following a significant flooding event that occurred in the city over the weekend.

The workshop was a collaborative effort between the Atlantic City Fire Department, Atlantic City Office of Emergency Management, and the Atlantic City Police Department. Together, they shared essential guidance on what residents should do if they experience flooding in their homes, including steps to protect property and ensure personal safety.

Participants learned practical strategies for emergency preparedness, such as how to create a flood safety plan, where to seek assistance, and how to minimize damage during severe weather. The hands-on discussion allowed residents to ask questions directly to city officials and emergency responders.

A highlight of the event was the distribution of FREE Flooding Preparedness Kits, which equipped attendees with essential tools and information for responding effectively to flood-related emergencies. Many of these kits were quickly put to good use as residents applied the knowledge they gained during the recent flood.

The workshop’s timing underscored the city’s proactive approach to community safety and disaster readiness. By offering this educational opportunity before a major weather event, the city demonstrated its strong commitment to empowering residents with knowledge and resources.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. and city officials commended the City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services for organizing the event and ensuring that lifesaving information reached diverse communities across the city.

The session also emphasized the importance of preparedness and community cooperation in responding to natural disasters. Residents were encouraged to remain vigilant, stay informed, and continue participating in future safety programs.

With ongoing climate challenges and the city’s coastal geography, workshops like this play a crucial role in protecting lives and property. The success of this event served as a reminder that education and readiness are key to building a resilient community.

item.title: Atlantic City on the Move: Mayor Small and NJDOT Announce Full Repaving of Pacific Avenue and Major Infrastructure Upgrades
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City advances $25M in upgrades—repaving Pacific, Atlantic, Baltic & MLK Blvd, enhancing signals, sidewalks & safety citywide.
item.content:encoded:
The momentum continues. In another milestone for Atlantic City’s infrastructure revitalization, Mayor Marty Small Sr., joined by the New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT), announced the full repaving of Pacific Avenue — one of the city’s most vital transportation corridors — as part of more than $25 million in ongoing infrastructure projects across the city.

‍

$5.3 Million in New Grant Funding Fuels Major Improvements

The New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT) recently awarded $5.3 million in new State and Federal grant funding to support several significant projects in Atlantic City, including the full repaving of Pacific Avenue and the construction of new sidewalks connecting Atlantic City High School and Chelsea Heights — a key safety improvement for students and families.

This funding builds on more than $25 million in active infrastructure projects already underway citywide, including improvements along Atlantic Avenue, Baltic Avenue, Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, and Tennessee Avenue. Together, these investments represent the largest coordinated infrastructure effort the city has seen in decades — aimed at making Atlantic City safer, stronger, and more connected.

“Under the Small Administration, relationships matter — and our strong partnership with state agencies like NJDOT is delivering real results for the people of the Great City of Atlantic City,” said Mayor Small. “This is a historic moment because, for the first time in a very long time, residents and visitors alike will experience newly paved roads through the main arteries of our great city. No previous administration has made this level of progress in such a short time. These grants are helping us transform Atlantic City’s infrastructure, while also making critical safety improvements that benefit everyone.”

“The revitalization of Pacific Avenue has been a priority for Governor Murphy and now that the signal synchronization is under contract, it is important to repave this major corridor from Maine Avenue to Albany Avenue,” said NJDOT Commissioner Fran O’Connor. “This is the gateway to the casino resorts, hotels, businesses, and famed Boardwalk. Building a walkway to link the Atlantic City High School to the city is an important safety improvement.”

‍

Infrastructure Projects Transforming the City

Across Atlantic City, infrastructure upgrades are reshaping the city’s streets, corridors, and connections between neighborhoods. The following projects are currently active:

  • Atlantic Avenue Repaving: From Tennessee to Albany Avenues, including corridor-wide safety and beautification enhancements.
  • Pacific Avenue Signal Optimization Project: Synchronizing 35 traffic signals and installing new fiber-optic infrastructure to improve traffic flow and safety.
  • Baltic Avenue Repaving: From Maine to North Carolina Avenues, with work continuing west to Missouri Avenue and plans for the Fairmount Avenue segment.
  • Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard Repaving: From Route 30 to Mediterranean Avenue, improving access and safety in key residential and commercial zones.
  • Pedestrian Connectivity: The addition of new sidewalks between Atlantic City High School and Chelsea Heights to improve walkability and student safety.

Building Momentum Across Every Neighborhood

With more than $25 million in infrastructure projects currently underway — and new State and Federal grants expanding the city’s capacity to deliver results — Atlantic City continues to build momentum, modernizing its streets, strengthening neighborhoods, and enhancing quality of life for residents, visitors, and investors alike.

The improvements mean smoother commutes for residents, safer routes for students and families, and modernized corridors that support small businesses and future development.

Atlantic City’s progress is visible in every direction — proof that strategic investment, collaboration, and leadership are paving the way for a stronger, more connected city.

item.title: Atlantic City Thanked CRDA, Ocean Casino Resort, and Showboat Hotel for Supporting Residents and First Responders During Nor’easter

item.description: The City of Atlantic City expressed heartfelt thanks to CRDA, Ocean Casino Resort, and Showboat Hotel Atlantic City for providing shelter, meals, and vital support to residents and First Responders during the recent nor’easter, reflecting the strength and unity of the community.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City extended a huge thank you to the NJ Casino Reinvestment Development Authority (CRDA) for providing critical support during the recent nor’easter. The CRDA generously loaned the Atlantic City Convention Center to serve as a temporary shelter and meal site for residents affected by the storm, offering a safe space and warm meals to those in need.

City officials expressed deep appreciation for the partnership and community spirit demonstrated by CRDA during one of the most challenging weather events of the season. Their quick response and willingness to assist made a significant difference in the city’s emergency relief efforts.

The City of Atlantic City Government also recognized the outstanding contributions of Ocean Casino Resort and Showboat Hotel Atlantic City, which provided meals to the city’s First Responders as they worked tirelessly around the clock to protect residents and visitors. Their generosity ensured that essential personnel were well-supported while performing their critical duties throughout the storm.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. and city leaders highlighted that such partnerships showcase the unity and compassion within the Atlantic City community. During times of crisis, collaboration among local organizations, businesses, and government entities strengthens the city’s resilience and reinforces the shared commitment to public safety.

The city noted that it was grateful to have community partners who consistently step up when help is needed most. These efforts demonstrated the true meaning of community care—neighbors, institutions, and leaders working together for the greater good.

As recovery efforts continued, the City of Atlantic City reaffirmed its commitment to working closely with local partners to support residents and ensure the city remains #ACStrong in the face of challenges.

item.title: Atlantic City Provided Emergency Shelter at Convention Center During Nor’easter

item.description: The City of Atlantic City operated an emergency shelter at the Atlantic City Convention Center during the nor’easter, staffed by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Atlantic City Police Department to assist residents displaced by the storm.
item.content:encoded:

The initiative was led by the Department of Health and Human Services in partnership with the Atlantic City Police Department, ensuring that displaced individuals received the care and support they needed.

Since Saturday, dedicated city staff and officers had been on-site around the clock to manage shelter operations, assist evacuees, and maintain safety within the facility. The emergency shelter provided a warm, safe, and secure environment for residents forced to leave their homes due to the storm’s effects.

The Atlantic City Convention Center served as a central hub for emergency response efforts, offering essential services such as meals, sleeping accommodations, and medical assistance for those affected.

City officials emphasized that the shelter would remain open until Tuesday, ensuring that anyone displaced by flooding, power outages, or other storm-related damages had a place to stay until conditions improved.

The collaboration between the Department of Health and Human Services and the Atlantic City Police Department reflected the city’s strong commitment to public welfare, particularly during severe weather emergencies.

This coordinated response demonstrated how Atlantic City’s government and community agencies worked hand in hand to prioritize safety and compassion for residents in need.

item.title: Atlantic City Officials Urged Residents to Move Vehicles to Wave Garage During Flood Warning
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Public Safety Officials urged residents in flood-prone areas to move their vehicles to the Wave Garage at Mississippi and Fairmount Avenues, offering free parking through 12 PM Tuesday to prevent flood-related vehicle damage.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City took proactive measures to ensure the safety of residents and their property during a period of anticipated flooding. Public Safety Officials issued an urgent advisory, urging all residents living in flood-prone areas to relocate their vehicles to the Wave Garage located at Mississippi and Fairmount Avenues.

This advisory was part of the city’s continuous effort to prevent potential vehicle damage caused by rising flood waters. The Wave Garage was opened to the public free of charge, allowing residents to safely park their vehicles through 12 PM Tuesday.

Officials emphasized the importance of swift action, noting that flood waters can severely damage vehicles left in low-lying areas. By providing a designated and secure parking facility, the city aimed to minimize property loss and maintain public safety throughout the duration of the weather event.

The City of Atlantic City Government, in coordination with its public safety departments, has consistently reminded residents to heed weather alerts and prepare accordingly. This initiative reflected the city’s dedication to community welfare and its readiness to respond promptly to emergencies.

Residents were encouraged to monitor official city channels for real-time updates on flood conditions, parking availability, and safety measures.

Through this precautionary measure, Atlantic City demonstrated its commitment to protecting both lives and property amid challenging weather conditions.

item.title: Atlantic City Public Schools Elementary and Middle School Athletes Gained Ground Through Fall Sports
item.dc:creator: Great Day Altantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Public Schools celebrated a strong fall sports season, as elementary and middle school athletes gained confidence, skill, and teamwork through soccer and cross-country programs focused on participation, inclusion, and fun.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Public Schools elementary and middle school athletes recently wrapped up a successful fall sports season, showcasing growth, teamwork, and community spirit across the district. From soccer fields to cross-country courses, students gained valuable experience in sportsmanship, perseverance, and skill development.

Under the leadership of Jason Lantz, the district’s Extracurricular Elementary Athletics Teacher Coordinator, the fall sports programs emphasized participation, fun, and inclusion. “The focus is on making sure every child gets playing time, enjoys the experience, and has fun,” Lantz shared, highlighting the district’s commitment to creating positive and enriching athletic opportunities for all students.

Elementary students participated in Round Robin Play, where teams rotated through soccer matches that encouraged collaboration and camaraderie across schools. Every player had the chance to step onto the field and contribute, fostering not only physical fitness but also confidence and teamwork. The games led up to the district’s soccer tournament, which took place on October 25, 2025.

Matches were hosted at key locations, including Chelsea Heights Field and Pop Lloyd Stadium, providing young athletes with the excitement of playing in recognized community venues. Alongside soccer, students also took part in cross-country races, discovering endurance sports while strengthening school spirit. The season culminated with a district championship race on November 3, 2025, bringing together runners from across the city.

For middle school students, the travel teams added another layer of experience. Both boys’ and girls’ soccer teams took on schools from neighboring districts, including Galloway Middle School, testing their skills and teamwork in a more competitive setting. Meanwhile, the middle school cross-country teams began their season with a spirited meet against Bridgeton, racing along Albany Avenue and the Boardwalk.

Lantz explained that these extracurricular programs were designed to give students a platform to grow athletically and personally. “Our goal is to give student-athletes the chance to try new sports, gain experience, and make lasting connections with peers across the district,” he said.

Parents, teachers, and community members played an important role in the season’s success, turning out in support of young athletes at every event. Their encouragement helped create an atmosphere of unity and pride, reinforcing Atlantic City’s dedication to youth development through sports.

As the season concluded, it became clear that the fall sports programs were about more than just competition—they were about building confidence, fostering teamwork, and strengthening bonds within the Atlantic City Public Schools community.

item.title: Rutgers University Students Explored Atlantic City’s Growth and Sustainability
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Students from Rutgers University joined the City of Atlantic City’s Planning & Development Department for a guided bus tour exploring development projects, environmental challenges, and sustainability opportunities. The visit encouraged innovative thinking and inspired students to reimagine the city’s future.
item.content:encoded:
Students from Rutgers University recently explored Atlantic City through a guided bus tour that highlighted the city’s ongoing development projects, environmental challenges, and opportunities for innovation. The immersive experience allowed participants to see firsthand how urban planning and sustainability intersect in a city known for its rich history and evolving landscape.

The tour, organized by the City of Atlantic City’s Planning & Development Department, aimed to inspire students to think critically about practical, long-term solutions that support the city’s revitalization.

During the visit, students focused on key urban challenges, including vacant lots and abandoned buildings, underutilized mega-structures, limited water access, and environmental vulnerabilities. These areas served as inspiration for their upcoming studio projects, where they will propose innovative strategies to enhance city life and promote resilience.

Stops on the tour included Bader Field, Gardner’s Basin, the Orange Loop, and several other notable sites that represent both the city’s potential and the work still to be done. Each location offered students an opportunity to assess how design, policy, and community engagement can come together to shape a sustainable urban future.

City officials and planners also shared insights about recent redevelopment initiatives, community partnerships, and efforts to balance growth with environmental responsibility.

For many students, this experience served as a real-world classroom, offering a deeper understanding of how planning decisions can impact local economies, ecosystems, and residents’ quality of life.

The collaboration between the City of Atlantic City and Rutgers University showcased how education and municipal innovation can work hand in hand to prepare the next generation of urban planners.

Through this initiative, Atlantic City continues to position itself as a living laboratory for sustainable urban transformation, providing valuable learning opportunities while welcoming fresh perspectives from emerging professionals.

item.title: A New Look, A Great Day: The Reimagined Great Day Gazette Brings Atlantic City Together
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Great Day Gazette celebrates Atlantic City’s growth, unity, and community spirit with the launch of the Great Day app, major development milestones, and vibrant local events—all underscoring that it truly was a Great Day in the City of Atlantic City.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City has officially unveiled its newly rebranded Great Day Gazette, ushering in a new chapter of storytelling, connection, and community pride. What began as an internal newsletter has grown into a dynamic publication that celebrates everything that makes Atlantic City an extraordinary place to live, work, and thrive.

The rebrand comes at an exciting time, aligning with the launch of the Great Day Atlantic City app—a digital platform designed to shine a light on the people, progress, and positive news happening across the city. Together, the Gazette and the app form a powerful communication hub, keeping residents, employees, and visitors informed about all the great things taking place within Atlantic City.

In his opening message, Mayor Marty Small Sr. expressed enthusiasm for the Gazette’s evolution and the city’s renewed focus on positivity and transparency. “There are way too many negative voices out there when it comes to the Great City of Atlantic City,” the Mayor said. “The Great Day platform gives all the positives, which far outweigh the negatives—the spotlight they deserve.”

This month’s issue of the Great Day Gazette is packed with inspiring stories, community highlights, and exciting updates. Readers can look back on the success of Great Day 2025, a day of motivation and team building for city employees dedicated to the memory of Chief of Staff Ernest Coursey. The event featured keynote speaker Nehemiah Davis, who encouraged city staff to focus on growth, resilience, and becoming the best versions of themselves.

The Gazette also covers the city’s presence at the first Atlantic City Strategic Communications Summit, hosted by Stockton University and the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs (DCA). There, the city’s Marketing Team—including Public Information Officer Andrew Kramer, Assistant PIO Adele Polk, Shennita Williams, and Ziggy Chau of Lucky PR—presented Great Day Atlantic City as a leading example of civic storytelling and community engagement. The summit emphasized collaboration and shared messaging across local institutions to build a stronger, unified voice for Atlantic City.

Readers will also find updates on major development and infrastructure projects. Mayor Small joined community leaders for the grand opening of The Seahaus Hotel and Cucina Del Mar, celebrating the continued growth of Atlantic City’s hospitality sector. Meanwhile, the city began the long-anticipated revitalization of Atlantic Avenue—a transformative project that includes new paving, traffic signal upgrades, ADA-compliant ramps, enhanced lighting, and beautification improvements designed to make the corridor safer and more welcoming for all.

Economic opportunity and small business growth are also front and center. The Gazette highlights the Small Business Micro Grant Program, providing reimbursement support for local businesses through federal ARPA funding, and the new food truck program opening two prime locations—Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park—to bring affordable dining options and entrepreneurial opportunities to the community.

In Public Safety News, the friendly rivalry between the Atlantic City Fire Department and Police Department took center stage during the first-ever Mayor’s Cup Softball Game. The community gathered at Pop Lloyd Stadium to cheer on both teams, celebrating camaraderie and civic pride. The issue also recognized newly promoted fire officers and honored the city’s first responders during the Atlantic City 9/11 Memorial Ceremony.

The Gazette continued its tradition of celebrating people and programs that make Atlantic City vibrant—from Senior Appreciation Day and Hispanic Heritage Month celebrations at City Hall, to new youth initiatives including the Youth Theater Program, Girl Scouts sessions, and Little Leapers gymnastics. Each story reflected the city’s ongoing mission to create inclusive, engaging opportunities for all residents—young and old alike.

Looking ahead, the issue also shared details on upcoming events that embody the city’s community spirit, including the Flood Safety Workshop, the Roll Out! Skating Party for National Coming Out Day, the Drive-In Movie & S’mores Night at Bader Field, and the much-anticipated Harvest Town Festival at Gardner’s Basin.

As the city continues to evolve, the Great Day Gazette stands as a symbol of connection and collaboration—highlighting the stories that too often go untold and celebrating the everyday efforts that make Atlantic City stronger. Whether it’s infrastructure progress, employee recognition, or community celebration, the Gazette captures it all.

Mayor Small summed it up best: “No other administration in Atlantic City history has given employees the amount of training, recognition, and opportunity they’re getting right now—and that’s something I’ll never let up on.”

Read the full October 2025 issue of the Great Day Gazette to stay informed, inspired, and connected to the city’s latest achievements and upcoming events. Because here in Atlantic City—every day truly is a Great Day.

item.title: Clean & Safe in Action: Atlantic City’s "Love Caters All" Shines on a Renewed Florida Avenue
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: Nancy Claud, owner of Love Caters All on S. Florida Avenue, purchased her property last year. Since then, she has had a front row seat to watch the area transform for the better.
item.content:encoded:
During the Clean & Safe segment of Mayor Marty Small, Sr.’s 2025 State of the City address, he highlighted the city’s continued efforts toenhance public safety by strategically adding police officers to areashistorically plagued by crime.
“We added extra presence on Florida, Georgia, and Bellevue Avenue, which has been a thorn in every administration’s side,” Mayor Small said during his presentation. “But we’re making progress now with our police officers over there.”
One local business owner sees the impact firsthand.
Nancy Claud, owner of Love Caters All at 30 S. Florida Avenue, purchased her property last year. Since then, she has had a front row seat to watch the area transform for the better and credits the improvement in safety as a key factor in her ability to grow her event planning business.
“In the beginning, those of you who know about Florida Avenue, it was a nightmare,” she said. “I went to Mayor Small’s office, and I explained the situation to him, and he addressed it with the Atlantic City Police Department, and every time I called his office, he helped me out, so I thank him for helping get Florida Avenue cleaned.”
With a renewed sense of security, Claud has been able to turn Love Caters All into a full-service business offering planning, decoration, and venue space for weddings and events — especially for clients looking for last-minute solutions. The business also features upstairs suites for overnight accommodation.
“It’s a full package, one-stop shop,” she said with a smile.
Now that safety is less of a concern at her property, Claud says she’s refocusing on her vision: providing elegance and comfort while creating job opportunities for residents.
“I would love for everyone to come to see something the city was missing,” she added. “We would love to host more Black theater – jazz, plays –so that’s something I would love to add to the city. I love Atlantic City. I think it’s a great city with great potential. I wouldn’t choose anywhere else.”
Based on what she's seen happen outside her business, she’s eager for others to witness the changes. “Please come check out Florida Avenue,” Claud said. “It’s a whole new world, and Mayor Small did help.”

item.title: Atlantic City’s Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program: Preparing Residents for Success
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.content:encoded:
For Atlantic City residents looking to build a brighter future, the Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program is here to help. Designed for those who are unemployed, looking to upskill, or seeking better opportunities, the program removes barriers to employment by combining training, career exploration, and hands-on certifications.

What the Program Offers

  • Soft Skills Training – Teamwork, communication, time management, adaptability, problem-solving
  • Workplace Readiness – 16-hour, in-person training required before advanced certification courses
  • Career Exploration with MECA System – Career planning, assessments, and hands-on projects
  • Hospitality Certifications – Courses from the American Hotel & Lodging Educational Institute:
    • Front Desk Representative (CFDR)
    • Guestroom Attendant (CGA)
    • Restaurant Server (CRS)
    • Maintenance Employee (CME)
    • Kitchen Cook (CKC)
    • Breakfast Attendant (CBA)
    • Guest Service Gold
  • Ongoing Support – Job interview referrals, career planning, and resources for long-term employment success

Beyond Skills: Building Careers

The program also provides personal development resources like The Success Profiler, Winning Colors, Financial Success tools, and anxiety management strategies — ensuring participants don’t just land a job, but build sustainable careers.

Why It Matters

The Job Readiness Program reflects Atlantic City’s commitment to workforce development, creating a pipeline of skilled residents ready to contribute to the city’s growth.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Honored Fallen K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department honored fallen K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke with a memorial ceremony at MLK and Atlantic Avenues, marking 55 years since his sacrifice. His legacy lives on through the Atlantic County K-9 Academy and the officers he continues to inspire.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department held a solemn memorial ceremony in honor of fallen K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke at the intersection of MLK and Atlantic Avenues in Atlantic City.

K-9 Officer Burke was tragically gunned down while on duty at that very intersection 55 years ago. Though decades have passed, his memory continued to live on through the Atlantic County K-9 Academy, which was named in his honor.

As one of the first officers to join the newly established K-9 force, Officer Burke left behind a lasting legacy of bravery and dedication. His commitment to service inspired generations of officers who followed in his footsteps.

The memorial ceremony was attended by several recruits from the John “Sonny” Burke Police K-9 Academy, representing the continuation of his work and the strength of the program built in his name.

Dignitaries and leaders in public safety also paid their respects. Attendees included Chief James Sarkos, Public Safety Director Sean Riggin, and Deputy Chiefs Christian Garofalo and Andrew Leonard, each recognizing the enduring impact of Officer Burke’s service and sacrifice.

A ceremonial wreath was dedicated by AC PBA Local 24 President Jules Schwenger, and placed beneath the street sign for Officer John “Sonny” Burke Avenue, ensuring his legacy remains a visible reminder for the community.

Adding a deeply personal touch to the event, three of K-9 Officer Burke’s brothers attended the ceremony. Among them, Greg Burke delivered an emotional speech, moving the crowd with heartfelt words of remembrance and love.

The gathering stood as a testament to the enduring respect and admiration for Officer Burke’s courage, as well as the unbreakable bond between the department, the academy, and the community he served. The memorial not only honored the past but also reaffirmed the department’s commitment to keeping alive the memory of those who gave the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty. By remembering K-9 Officer Peter John “Sonny” Burke, the Atlantic City Police Department ensured that his legacy of service and sacrifice would continue to inspire future generations.

item.title: Atlantic City to Welcome Food Trucks to Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City will soon welcome food trucks to Gardner’s Basin and O’Donnell Memorial Park, creating new opportunities for local vendors and fresh dining experiences for the community. Up to eight food trucks per site began operating daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM starting November 1st.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially expanded its food culture by allowing food trucks to operate in two designated locations. Mayor Marty Small announced that the initiative would provide new opportunities for vendors and offer residents and visitors more diverse dining choices.

Food trucks will be permitted to operate at Gardner’s Basin near the Seawall parking lot and at O’Donnell Memorial Park along Captain John O'Donnell Parkway. Both areas were selected to attract locals and tourists while ensuring convenience and accessibility.

Under this new program, up to eight registered and approved food trucks were allowed at each site. The city ensured proper management by clearly marking the vending areas with designated signage.

To accommodate both daytime and evening crowds, the hours of operation were set daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM, beginning on November 1st. This schedule allowed vendors to serve breakfast, lunch, dinner, and late-night snacks.

Applications for interested vendors are available on the City of Atlantic City Government website, by Monday, October 6th (select Food Truck). To be considered, applicants must:

  • Submit a completed application
  • Pay the required application and license fees
  • Provide certificate of insurance

This effort represented part of the city’s broader push to support local businesses and attract more visitors. Food trucks offered unique cuisines, quick service, and a fresh layer of vibrancy to Atlantic City’s community spaces.

Mayor Small emphasized that the program would help small businesses grow while giving residents more affordable dining options. The city also encouraged local vendors to participate, making sure the opportunity supported the community first.

This initiative marks a new chapter for Atlantic City’s public spaces, blending local entrepreneurship with community enjoyment in a way that celebrated both tradition and innovation.

By November, visitors will be able to experience the new offerings and enjoy freshly prepared meals from some of the region’s best mobile kitchens and Atlantic City's vibrant and diverse food cultures.

item.title: Positive Culture Shift for Atlantic City Employees Continues with Mayor Small’s ‘Great Day’ Event
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: The annual 'Great Day' event is Mayor Small's signature initiative to strengthen workforce climate and culture, boost morale, and unite City of Atlantic City employees as one team.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Mayor Marty Small, Sr. has long said that to truly build Atlantic City, the transformation must begin from the inside out. Since becoming mayor in October 2019, he’s turned that vision into action, reshaping the culture of City Hall and setting a new standard for local government. From his first days in office, Mayor Small raised expectations for every department and made accountability a cornerstone of his administration. He’s expanded opportunities for advancement through internal mobility, promotions, and well-earned raises, ensuring that dedicated employees see a future in public service. Just as importantly, he has invested heavily in training programs that give staff unprecedented professional development and the skills needed to better serve Atlantic City taxpayers.

That commitment came into full focus at this year’s Great Day 2025 event held at the Showboat Resort for a third straight year. This is the mayor’s signature initiative to strengthen workforce climate and culture, boost morale, and unite City of Atlantic City employees as one team. It’s the only time each year every city worker gathers under one roof outside city buildings to receive key organizational updates directly from the mayor and gain fresh perspective from nationally recognized outside sources.

This year’s motivational speaker was philanthropist Nehemiah Davis, who shared his inspiring journey from humble beginnings in Philadelphia—where he frequently found himself getting into trouble—to becoming a prominent figure dedicated to helping others transform their lives. Addressing City of Atlantic City employees, Davis encouraged them to write down the affirmation: “I’m committed and focused on making this the best year ever.” He emphasized how mindset shifts can lead to real change and challenged staff to stop saying, “I have to go to work,” and instead embrace the privilege of being able to say, “I get to go to work”— especially in a place like Atlantic City.

Great Day 2025 carried added significance this year, as it was held in memory of the late Chief of Staff Ernest Coursey. Known for his unwavering dedication as a public servant and his deep care for city employees, Coursey left a lasting legacy. In his honor, all staff wore commemorative shirts, and the city announced the upcoming launch of the Coursey Cares Health& Wellness Challenge, an initiative aimed at promoting small, sustainable lifestyle changes that employees can carry with them for life.

‍

Following the professional development portion of the day, employees get to relax and connect at Showboat’s Island Waterpark, and this year was no exception. With more than 700 employees spread across City Hall, the Public Safety Building, the Public Works Yard, and other locations, some staff members rarely cross paths, if ever. But on this one day a year, in the open, informal setting of the waterpark, colleagues can interact, bond, and build stronger relationships. Team building is a cornerstone of the Small Administration. It’s why each department is tasked with organizing its own annual retreat outside the Great Day event, and why Mayor Small personally leads a retreat for his directors.

A recent article from The Press of Atlantic City covering Great Day 2025 failed to spotlight the most critical component of the event, which is Mayor Small’s mission to raise expectations, invest in employee development, and celebrate the city's workforce. Mayor Small is demonstrating that a city government can evolve from within—and Great Day 2025 is a shining example of that transformation. His message is clear: when the workforce is motivated, well-trained, and connected, the entire Atlantic City community reaps the rewards.

‍

Equally, the Atlantic City Arts Foundation provided unwavering support, reflecting its ongoing commitment to fostering creativity throughout the city.

At the heart of the project was artist Kenneth Faulk, whose talent and dedication turned the vision into reality. His work captured the energy and vibrancy of Atlantic City while offering a meaningful tribute to the spirit of resilience symbolized by the lifeboat.

The unveiling ceremony drew community members, leaders, and art enthusiasts who gathered to admire the mural and celebrate the teamwork that made it possible. It served as a reminder that public art can do more than beautify a space—it can connect people, tell stories, and strengthen community pride.

By placing this lifeboat mural at Gardner’s Basin, Atlantic City not only added a striking work of art to its landscape but also reinforced its commitment to supporting local artists, organizations, and cultural initiatives that make the city unique.

This moment marked yet another step in Atlantic City’s ongoing efforts to blend history, culture, and creativity into spaces that welcome and inspire everyone.

The mural now stands as a testament to what can be achieved when artists, organizations, and the community come together in the name of beauty and progress.

item.title: Atlantic City Bids Farewell to New Jersey Avenue School
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City bid farewell to the historic New Jersey Avenue School, celebrating its legacy with alumni, teachers, and community members. Though the building has closed, its impact and memories will live on in generations of Atlantic City families.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City gathered the community to honor and say farewell to the historic New Jersey Avenue School, a building that shaped generations of students and families.

The farewell ceremony was not only a goodbye to a school building but also a celebration of the memories, experiences, and connections that defined it. Former teachers, principals, and alumni came together to share heartfelt reflections on how the school touched their lives.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. offered a personal memory during the event, recalling the moment he discovered his own childhood “artwork” still displayed on the classroom wall decades later. His reflection highlighted how deeply the school was woven into the history of Atlantic City families.

The event was filled with emotion, pride, and nostalgia. Attendees spoke of classrooms that once buzzed with learning, friendships that lasted a lifetime, and the teachers who inspired and guided countless students.

As the day came to a close, alumni joined together in song, performing the school anthem, “To You We Sing New Jersey.” The powerful moment reminded everyone that while the physical building may no longer stand, the legacy of the school would continue to live on in the people it shaped.

The New Jersey Avenue School left a lasting impact on Atlantic City, representing not only an institution of education but also a symbol of community, resilience, and shared history.

Even as the city evolves, the memories created within those walls will remain cherished. The school’s story became part of Atlantic City’s greater story — one of growth, change, and honoring the foundations that brought the community together.

The farewell ceremony underscored that schools are more than brick and mortar. They are the places where identities are formed, values are taught, and futures are built. New Jersey Avenue School was a cornerstone of this truth, leaving behind a legacy that will never fade.

item.title: Kelsey’s Atlantic City Honored with the Economic Growth & Development Award
item.dc:creator: Great Day Altantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City honored Kelsey’s Atlantic City with the Economic Growth & Development Award, recognizing the Jackson family’s impact on the community‍
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, progress is not just measured in buildings or investments — it is reflected in the success of the small businesses that form the city’s backbone. Through its Keep It Local campaign, led by the Economic Development division under the Planning & Development Department, the City of Atlantic City recognized the vital role that local entrepreneurs play in shaping the community’s future.

One highlight of this effort was the presentation of the Economic Growth & Development Award to Kelsey’s Atlantic City, a local restaurant that has become a cultural landmark. For years, owners Kelsey and Kimberly Jackson worked tirelessly to serve not only food, but also hospitality that felt like home.

From its very beginning, Kelsey’s was more than a place to eat. It was a gathering space where neighbors could share southern comfort meals, enjoy live music, and feel connected. It showed how a business could grow into a community institution, weaving itself into the everyday life of Atlantic City.

With three locations across the city, Kelsey’s also became a driver of local economic activity. By welcoming both residents and visitors, it drew people into neighborhoods, fueled local spending, and created job opportunities. In doing so, it embodied the spirit of growth and resilience that defines Atlantic City.

The recognition of Kelsey’s demonstrated how local businesses reflect the larger momentum happening in the city. As Atlantic City invested in its neighborhoods, public spaces, and small enterprises, the success stories of people like the Jackson family became proof that the city’s vision of renewal was not only possible but already taking shape.

Receiving the award was described by Kelsey Jackson as “an honor and a privilege.” He emphasized that the acknowledgment was a testament to the dedication and effort put into the business over the years. Kimberly Jackson added that Atlantic City itself was “doing better than ever,” reflecting the citywide growth happening all around them.

Stories like Kelsey’s show why Atlantic City is more than a place to visit — it is a city to believe in. It is a place where hard work is recognized, where local culture thrives, and where economic development goes hand in hand with community spirit.

This recognition stood as a reminder that Atlantic City is not only a destination for entertainment but also a community where people can put down roots, build businesses, and create lasting impact. It is a city where individuals can find opportunity, connection, and pride.

Every award, every campaign, and every small business success adds to a bigger story — a story of a city moving forward together. Atlantic City is not just about what it offers to visitors; it is about what it provides to its own residents: a place to live, to work, and to grow.

item.title: Atlantic City Fire Department Celebrated Promotions of Three Dedicated Members
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Fire Department honored three of its dedicated members with promotions during a ceremony led by Mayor Marty Small Sr. The event celebrated the advancements of Kevin Munn, Gregory DeSantis, and Matthew Myrtetus, marking an important milestone in their careers.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City recently recognized the outstanding service and dedication of three members of the Atlantic City Fire Department through a formal promotional ceremony. The event highlighted the commitment of these individuals who have consistently demonstrated leadership, professionalism, and unwavering service to the community.

During the ceremony, Mayor Marty Small Sr. administered the Oath of Office, officially affirming the new ranks of the promoted firefighters. The gathering brought together city officials, colleagues, family members, and community supporters to honor this important milestone in their careers.

Among those recognized was Kevin Munn, who was promoted to the position of Deputy Chief. His years of experience and leadership within the department prepared him for this vital role, where he would oversee operations and ensure the continued safety and efficiency of the department.

Gregory DeSantis was also honored with a promotion to Battalion Chief. Known for his dedication and ability to lead under pressure, he stepped into this position with a responsibility to guide and support his fellow firefighters during emergencies and daily operations.

Completing the trio of promotions, Matthew Myrtetus advanced to the rank of Captain. His promotion recognized his commitment to mentorship, training, and frontline leadership in serving Atlantic City residents.

The promotional ceremony was not only a celebration of these individuals but also a testament to the strength and unity of the Atlantic City Fire Department. The advancements symbolized the department’s ongoing mission to cultivate leadership and ensure the highest level of emergency response for the city.

Mayor Small, in his role as the city’s leader, emphasized the importance of honoring these milestones. By administering the oath personally, he reaffirmed the city’s support for the fire department and its members who risk their lives for the safety of Atlantic City’s residents.

The promotions reflected the values of dedication, integrity, and excellence that define the department. Each newly promoted officer carried forward the responsibility of maintaining the trust and confidence of the community they serve.

The event concluded with well-wishes for success in their new positions, with both city officials and fellow firefighters expressing pride and encouragement.

The Atlantic City Professional Firefighters NJ FMBA Local 8 also extended its congratulations, highlighting the collective support and camaraderie that unite the department and its members.

item.description: The City of Atlantic City reintroduced the Great Day Atlantic City platform and launched the Great Day app during the Strategic Communications Summit, highlighting a new era of collaboration and community connection. item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City participated in the Atlantic City Strategic Communications Summit, hosted in collaboration with the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs and Stockton University. This gathering marked an important milestone as Atlantic City worked toward developing an authentic message that truly reflects the city’s energy, diversity, and potential. Participants came together with a shared goal: to elevate Atlantic City’s narrative and ensure that its story is told in a way that resonates with both residents and visitors.

During the summit, the City of Atlantic City - Government proudly reintroduced the Great Day Atlantic City platform. This initiative served as a vital tool to promote community engagement, highlight local opportunities, and strengthen Atlantic City’s image across various audiences.

In addition, the city officially launched the Great Day app, an accessible resource designed to keep residents, visitors, and investors informed. The app provided critical information about city events, updates, and services, giving the community a convenient way to stay connected to all that Atlantic City had to offer.

The event was made possible with the strong collaboration of partners including Visit Atlantic City, the New Jersey Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, community development corporations, and other local organizations. Their presence and active participation highlighted a shared commitment to advancing the city’s growth and unity.

Community partners such as the Chelsea EDC, Ducktown AC, Inlet Community Development Corporation, and Midtown Atlantic City CDC played a key role in discussions, showing the collective effort to create meaningful change and amplify Atlantic City’s voice.

The Strategic Communications Summit demonstrated the importance of collaboration, innovation, and forward-thinking leadership. It reflected the city’s dedication to aligning its communication strategy with the needs and aspirations of its community.

By relaunching the Great Day Atlantic City platform and unveiling the Great Day app, Atlantic City reinforced its pledge to strengthen its identity and better connect with residents and visitors alike. This marked not just a step, but a leap forward in building a brighter, more connected future for the city.

The summit also underscored the power of partnership. It showed that when city officials, community organizations, and local stakeholders work hand in hand, they can craft a stronger narrative and take bold actions that benefit the entire community.

Ultimately, the event stood as a clear example of Atlantic City’s ongoing progress. It reflected a vision rooted in unity, pride, and a commitment to growth — ensuring that the city continues to thrive and position itself as a dynamic place to live, visit, and invest.

item.title: Atlantic City Senior Services Strengthened Community Bonds Through Monthly Bowling Club
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contriutors
item.description: The Atlantic City Senior Services division hosted its monthly Bowling Club, celebrating friendships new and old while providing retirees with a fun, active, and meaningful way to stay socially connected. The program reflected the city’s dedication to enhancing the lives of older residents through community-focused initiatives.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Senior Services division continued its efforts to provide meaningful social opportunities for retirees with its monthly Bowling Club gathering, an event that celebrated friendships new and old while promoting active lifestyles and community engagement.

This month’s gathering once again brought seniors together for an afternoon of activity, laughter, and camaraderie. The Bowling Club, a popular recurring program, has become a cornerstone event for many older residents who look forward to reconnecting with familiar faces and meeting new friends in a relaxed, welcoming setting.

City officials emphasized that programs like the Bowling Club were created to address one of the most common challenges of retirement: how to meet new people and remain socially engaged after leaving the workforce. By providing regular opportunities for seniors to gather, Atlantic City ensured that residents remained connected, supported, and active.

Participants shared stories, enjoyed friendly competition, and celebrated one another’s successes on the lanes. More than just a recreational outing, the event highlighted the importance of maintaining strong social networks in retirement, a factor proven to benefit both mental and physical health.

For many seniors, the monthly event was more than just about bowling—it was about belonging. Attendees expressed gratitude for the chance to form bonds, rekindle existing relationships, and create lasting memories. The club gave retirees a sense of purpose and community, easing the transition into life after full-time employment.

The Atlantic City Senior Services division has long prioritized initiatives that enrich the lives of older adults. Staff members noted that the Bowling Club complemented other programs designed to keep seniors engaged, active, and connected to their peers. Together, these efforts reflected the city’s broader commitment to improving the quality of life for its aging population.

In addition to the social benefits, the event encouraged gentle physical activity, helping participants stay healthy in a fun, accessible way. City representatives stressed that wellness comes not only from exercise but also from positive relationships, and the Bowling Club brought both elements together seamlessly.

The program also provided a platform for seniors to engage with city staff, ensuring that the needs and voices of older residents continued to be heard. By maintaining a consistent presence in the community, Atlantic City Senior Services reinforced its role as a vital resource for local retirees.

As the monthly event concluded, officials encouraged more retirees to take part in upcoming Bowling Club gatherings. The program remained open to all seniors interested in trying something new, meeting people, or simply enjoying an afternoon of fun.

The success of the Bowling Club underscored Atlantic City’s commitment to creating inclusive spaces where seniors could thrive. By celebrating friendships new and old, the city demonstrated that retirement can be a beginning, not an end, when it comes to building meaningful relationships and staying engaged with the community.

item.title: Atlantic City Highlighted Community Creativity at 48 Blocks Festival

item.description: The City of Atlantic City praised the Atlantic City Arts Foundation for hosting the 48 Blocks Festival, celebrating creativity, culture, and community. item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City extended its appreciation to the Atlantic City Arts Foundation for successfully organizing the 48 Blocks Festival, a multi-day celebration of the arts that transformed neighborhoods into spaces of creativity and connection over the weekend.

The festival, which has become one of the city’s signature cultural events, brought together residents, visitors, artists, and community groups in a shared experience that highlighted the power of art to unite and inspire. From murals and installations to live performances and workshops, the 48 Blocks Festival showcased the wide range of talent and innovation thriving in Atlantic City.

City officials emphasized that the festival underscored Atlantic City’s ongoing efforts to support cultural growth and encourage artistic expression. They praised the Atlantic City Arts Foundation for its leadership in curating the event and for continuing to provide a platform where creativity and community intersect.

In addition to adult-focused activities, the city recognized the important role of its Youth Services Division, which organized programs that gave children and teens the opportunity to engage in hands-on artistic projects. These youth-centered initiatives allowed participants to explore their creative sides, build confidence, and gain new skills in a supportive environment.

Parents and families noted that these activities were not only fun but also enriching, offering young people constructive outlets to channel their energy and imagination. The 48 Blocks Festival also highlighted the contributions of local artists whose work reflected the diversity and cultural richness of Atlantic City.
